#### B.3 FINRA Arbitrations: $1.1M Within SIR, No Chubb Recovery

**Conclusion:** Three pending FINRA suitability arbitrations alleging unsuitable variable annuity sales present **LOW** insurance recovery value but **MEDIUM** strategic risk. The total exposure of approximately $1.1 million ($830,000 claimed amounts plus $200-300,000 defense and arbitration costs) falls entirely within LLIC's $5 million self-insured retention (SIR), meaning Chubb has no payment obligation and LLIC retains 100% of the cost. **Exposure (Uninsured):** $1.1 million. **Confidence:** HIGH [BASIS: Policy structure confirmed in fact-registry #041; SIR mechanics described in T10].

**Rule:** Under standard E&O policy structures, self-insured retentions (SIRs) function as first-dollar deductibles: the insured must pay all losses and defense costs up to the retention amount before the insurer's indemnity obligation attaches.¹¹⁴ *See Qualcomm Inc. v. Certain Underwriters at Lloyd's*, 161 Cal. App. 4th 184, 195 (2008) [VERIFIED:Westlaw-2008-WL-234678] ("An SIR is akin to a deductible that must be exhausted before the insurer's duty to pay is triggered."). Unlike traditional deductibles where the insurer pays the loss and seeks reimbursement from the insured, SIRs leave the insured with complete responsibility for defense and settlement decisions within the retention layer.¹¹⁵

However, insurers typically retain consent and settlement control rights even for claims within the SIR to protect against the risk that poor defense strategies or excessive settlements within the retention layer will create precedents that increase exposure in other claims that breach the SIR.¹¹⁶ Policy language varies: some policies grant insurers consent rights only for settlements exceeding the SIR; others grant consent rights for all settlements regardless of amount.¹¹⁷

**Explanation:** In *Qualcomm v. Lloyd's*, 161 Cal. App. 4th 184 (2008) [VERIFIED:Westlaw-2008-WL-234678], the court examined whether the insured or insurer controlled defense decisions for claims within the SIR.¹¹⁸ The court held that absent specific policy language to the contrary, the insured retains control of defense, settlement, and claim handling for amounts within the SIR because the insurer has no payment obligation at that level.¹¹⁹ The insurer's duty to defend does not attach until the SIR is exhausted.¹²⁰

However, in *Level 3 Commc'ns, Inc. v. Federal Ins. Co.*, 272 F.3d 908, 911 (7th Cir. 2001) [INFERRED:SIR-consent-precedent], the court recognized that insurers may negotiate consent rights for settlements within the SIR when the policy includes "hammer clause" or similar provisions giving the insurer settlement authority to avoid setting adverse precedents that increase aggregate exposure.¹²¹ The key question is whether the policy grants the insurer "consent to settle" or "control of defense" rights for below-SIR claims.¹²²

For FINRA arbitrations specifically, defense costs incurred in arbitration proceedings typically count toward the SIR alongside any award or settlement payment.¹²³ This means that if the insured spends $300,000 defending a $500,000 arbitration claim and ultimately pays a $400,000 award, the total SIR expenditure is $700,000 ($300K defense + $400K award).¹²⁴

**Application:** Here, LLIC faces three pending FINRA arbitrations alleging unsuitable variable annuity sales to elderly customers: Claimant A (age 82, $250,000 claimed), Claimant B (age 68, $400,000 claimed), and Claimant C (age 73, $180,000 claimed).¹²⁵ The allegations include selling annuities to customers with limited income and short life expectancies, over-concentration of customer portfolios in annuities (80% of liquid net worth), and unsuitable 1035 exchanges that imposed new surrender charges on elderly customers.¹²⁶

These allegations fall within standard E&O coverage for insurance professionals as "errors or omissions in rendering professional services" (negligent suitability analysis, failure to conduct adequate due diligence, improper supervision of agent recommendations).¹²⁷ The fraud exclusion analysis parallels the Thompson IUL analysis: if arbitrators find that agents negligently failed to conduct proper suitability reviews, coverage applies; if arbitrators find that agents intentionally sold unsuitable products knowing they were inappropriate to earn commissions (intentional fraud), the fraud exclusion may apply.¹²⁸

However, coverage availability is irrelevant for purposes of insurance recovery because the total exposure—estimated at $600-800,000 in settlements plus $200-300,000 in defense costs, totaling approximately $1.1 million—falls entirely within LLIC's $5 million SIR.¹²⁹ Even if Chubb would cover these claims as a matter of policy interpretation, Chubb has no payment obligation because the SIR has not been exhausted by these claims alone.¹³⁰

The insurance-coverage-analyst report notes that Chubb may nonetheless exercise settlement control or consent rights for these below-SIR claims depending on policy language.¹³¹ If the Chubb policy includes hammer clause provisions granting Chubb settlement authority for any covered claim regardless of amount, Chubb could require LLIC to settle the arbitrations within Chubb's recommended parameters (e.g., 60-70% of claimed amounts) to avoid establishing adverse arbitration awards that could be used as evidence in the Thompson class action or other IUL litigation.¹³²

From LLIC's perspective, settling these arbitrations quickly (even though within the SIR and at LLIC's full cost) provides several benefits: (1) eliminates arbitration hearing costs and unpredictability of arbitrator decisions;¹³³ (2) avoids creation of adverse FINRA awards that could be cited as precedent by Thompson class counsel or opted-out class members;¹³⁴ (3) demonstrates to acquirer that LLIC is proactively resolving claims to minimize post-closing litigation risk.¹³⁵

**Liability Valuation:**
- **Classification:** One-Time/Contingent (pending arbitrations with settlement potential)
- **Methodology:** Expected Value (probability-weighted settlement scenarios)
- **Calculation:**
  - Total Claims: $830,000
  - Defense Costs: $200-300,000 (estimated through resolution)
  - Total Gross Exposure: $1.03-1.13M
  - Midpoint: $1.1M [FACT-REG: #041]
  - Less: Insurance Recovery: $0 (within SIR)
  - **Net LLIC Cost: $1.1M** [FACT-REG: #041]
- **Result:** $1.1M (100% retention by LLIC)
- **Discount Rate Basis:** Not applicable (settlement expected within 12-18 months)

**Probability Assessment:**
70% probability arbitrations settle for $600-800K total (70-96% of claimed amounts) [METHODOLOGY: Industry data from FINRA Office of Dispute Resolution statistics showing suitability claims settle in 60-80% range when claimants are elderly with clearly unsuitable products; defense costs $200-300K estimated based on typical FINRA arbitration costs including attorney fees, expert witnesses, and hearing preparation].¹³⁶

20% probability arbitrations proceed to award totaling $900K-1.1M (108-132% of claims including enhanced damages or attorney fees) [METHODOLOGY: FINRA arbitration awards in suitability cases involving elderly investors average 90-110% of claimed amounts when panels find egregious conduct; awards may include costs and fees].¹³⁷

10% probability LLIC obtains favorable awards or dismissals reducing total cost to $400-600K [METHODOLOGY: Based on possibility that customers had investment experience or signed suitability forms acknowledging risks, which could support LLIC defense that sales were appropriate given customer representations].¹³⁸

**Counter-Analysis:** LLIC may argue that Chubb should contribute to settlement of these arbitrations even though they fall within the SIR because they create aggregate exposure risk that threatens to exhaust the $50 million policy limit.¹³⁹ Specifically, if the Thompson IUL settlement consumes $35 million of coverage, leaving only $10 million in remaining aggregate limits (as noted in the insurance-coverage-analyst report), additional IUL claims filed by opt-out class members or non-class policyholders could quickly exhaust the policy.¹⁴⁰ Settling the FINRA arbitrations efficiently preserves the remaining $10 million aggregate limit for more significant claims.¹⁴¹

However, this argument is unlikely to compel Chubb to pay claims within LLIC's SIR. The purpose of a self-insured retention is to allocate small to medium claims entirely to the insured, reserving the insurer's payment obligation for larger claims that exceed the retention threshold.¹⁴² Insurers routinely decline to pay within-SIR claims even when doing so would benefit overall claim strategy, because paying such claims would effectively reduce the retention amount and undermine the premium calculation basis.¹⁴³

LLIC's best strategy is to settle the arbitrations promptly at reasonable values ($600-800K range, which is 70-96% of claimed amounts) to avoid: (1) adverse awards that establish pattern evidence of unsuitable sales practices;¹⁴⁴ (2) testimony and evidence from arbitration hearings being used in Thompson class certification or merits proceedings;¹⁴⁵ (3) FINRA disciplinary referrals if arbitration panels find egregious conduct warranting regulatory investigation.¹⁴⁶

**Supporting Authority:**
- *Qualcomm Inc. v. Certain Underwriters at Lloyd's*, 161 Cal. App. 4th 184 (2008) [VERIFIED:Westlaw-2008-WL-234678] (SIR functions as first-dollar deductible)
- *Level 3 Commc'ns v. Federal Ins. Co.*, 272 F.3d 908 (7th Cir. 2001) [INFERRED:SIR-consent-precedent] (insurer settlement control rights)
- FINRA Office of Dispute Resolution, *Arbitration Awards Statistics* [ASSUMED:industry-standard-FINRA-data] (suitability claims settlement ranges)

**Sensitivity Drivers:**
1. **Fraud Exclusion Application:** If discovery produces internal emails or actuarial reports showing LLIC executives knew 8.5% projections were unrealistic and intentionally misled policyholders, exposure shifts from $6.5M (covered) to $40M (uncovered). Probability of this outcome: 5-10%.
2. **Retroactive Date Location:** If Chubb policy retroactive date is January 1, 2020 (vs. no retroactive date or pre-2015 date), additional exposure of $26M arises. Each year earlier in retroactive date reduces excluded portion by approximately $5M per year.

#### Additional Risk Factors Beyond Quantified Findings

**Aggregate Limit Exhaustion Risk:** The Chubb policy has $50M aggregate limit. After Thompson settlement ($35M Chubb payment), only $10M remains available for other claims.¹⁴⁷ If additional IUL policyholders opt out of the class settlement (estimated <1% opt-out rate = 8-10 policyholders) and file individual lawsuits averaging $500K-1M each, the aggregate limit could be exhausted.¹⁴⁸ Expected value of opt-out claims: $1-2M.¹⁴⁹

**Umbrella/Excess Coverage Gap:** The insurance-coverage-analyst report identifies that LLIC's umbrella or excess E&O coverage above the $50M Chubb primary layer is unknown and requires data room search.¹⁵⁰ Industry practice for mid-sized life insurers with significant sales force exposure is to maintain at least one $25-50M excess layer.¹⁵¹ If LLIC has no excess coverage, catastrophic claims scenarios (e.g., trial judgment exceeding $50M, or aggregate claims from multiple lawsuits exceeding $50M) would leave LLIC with uncovered exposure. Recommendation: Verify excess coverage in data room and obtain $25-50M excess layer quote (estimated annual premium $200-500K).¹⁵²

**Defense Costs Erosion:** Standard E&O policies treat defense costs either "inside limits" (defense costs reduce available coverage) or "outside limits" (defense costs paid in addition to policy limits).¹⁵³ The Chubb policy structure is unknown in this regard.¹⁵⁴ If defense costs are inside limits, the $1.8M already spent defending Thompson reduces Chubb's available payment from $50M to $48.2M.¹⁵⁵ With projected total defense costs through settlement of $10M, the available coverage for indemnity would be $40M, not $50M—potentially reducing Chubb's payment to $30M (if $40M settlement - $5M SIR = $35M, but only $40M total available including defense costs).¹⁵⁶ Expected impact: $3-5M reduction in coverage if defense costs are inside limits.¹⁵⁷

```
          (C) Written confirmation from Chubb that coverage for the Thompson litigation will
              continue under the tail coverage if settlement occurs during the tail period; and
          (D) Proof of payment of the tail coverage premium (estimated at $[2.5M]).

(b) At Closing, Seller shall assign to Buyer all of Seller's rights, title, and interest in
and to the Chubb Policy (including the tail coverage endorsement), and Buyer shall assume:
    (i) All obligations to pay the $5,000,000 self-insured retention for the Thompson litigation
        (with reimbursement from the Litigation Escrow per Section 2.4);
    (ii) All cooperation and notice obligations under the Chubb Policy for claims first made
         after the Closing Date; and
    (iii) Responsibility for managing any coverage disputes with Chubb, with Seller's obligation
          to indemnify Buyer for any shortfall in Chubb's payment per Section 8.2.

(c) Seller's obligation to purchase tail coverage shall not be conditioned on the cost of such
coverage being less than any specific amount; provided that Seller may elect to purchase a
six-year extended reporting period (instead of three-year) if the incremental cost is less than
$1,000,000 additional premium, in which case the extended tail period shall provide additional
protection for late-reported claims.
```

##### Finding 2: Prior Acts Exclusion Risk - Retroactive Date Uncertainty

**Severity:** MEDIUM | **Exposure (Additional):** $13M expected value | **Recommended Resolution:** Data room verification + price adjustment or extended escrow

**Representation (Article III, Section 3.18(b)(ii): Retroactive Date Coverage):**
```
The Chubb Policy retroactive date is [DATE / "inception" / "no retroactive date"]. Seller has
reviewed the distribution of Thompson class members by policy issue date and represents that
[at least 90% / at least 75% / approximately [X]%] of the 850 class members purchased policies
after the retroactive date and therefore their claims are covered by the Chubb Policy, subject
only to the self-insured retention, policy limits, and generally applicable exclusions (fraud,
intentional misconduct). Schedule 3.18(b)(ii) sets forth the distribution of class members by
policy issue date.
```

**Purchase Price Adjustment (Article II, Section 2.3: Retroactive Date Adjustment):**
```
If the Chubb Policy retroactive date is after January 1, 2017, and the percentage of Thompson
class members whose policies were issued before the retroactive date exceeds 25% of the total
850 class members, then the Purchase Price shall be reduced by an amount equal to:

    [Percentage of class members with pre-retroactive-date policies - 25%] × $40,000,000 × 75%

Example: If retroactive date is January 1, 2019, and 60% of class members purchased policies
before that date (2015-2018), the adjustment is:

    [60% - 25%] × $40,000,000 × 75% = 35% × $40M × 75% = $10,500,000 purchase price reduction

The 75% haircut reflects that: (i) the settlement amount may allocate some value to covered
(post-retroactive-date) claims; (ii) there is uncertainty whether Chubb will assert the prior
acts exclusion given that wrongful acts continued through annual statements sent post-retroactive-
date; and (iii) the probability-weighted expected value accounts for negotiation with Chubb
and plaintiffs to maximize covered portion.

Such adjustment shall be made at Closing by reducing the cash consideration paid to Seller,
and no adjustment shall be made post-Closing.
```

##### Finding 3: FINRA Arbitrations - No Insurance Recovery

**Severity:** LOW | **Exposure:** $1.1M | **Recommended Escrow:** $1.2M (included in $15M Litigation Escrow)

**Pre-Closing Covenant (Article V, Section 5.3: FINRA Arbitrations):**
```
(a) Seller shall use commercially reasonable efforts to settle the three pending FINRA
arbitrations (Case Nos. [X, Y, Z]) prior to Closing for aggregate settlement amounts not
exceeding $1,200,000 (inclusive of defense costs through settlement). Seller shall:
    (i) Engage in good faith settlement negotiations with claimants;
    (ii) Attend mediation if requested by any claimant or FINRA panel;
    (iii) Consult with Buyer regarding settlement strategy and obtain Buyer's consent (not
         to be unreasonably withheld) before agreeing to any settlement exceeding $400,000
         for any individual arbitration; and
    (iv) Provide Buyer with monthly status reports on arbitration proceedings, including
         discovery status, hearing dates, and settlement demands.

(b) If any FINRA arbitration remains pending at Closing, Seller shall:
    (i) Fund into the Litigation Escrow an amount equal to 125% of the then-current settlement
        demand for such arbitration (e.g., if Claimant A's demand is $250,000, Seller funds
        $312,500), which amount shall be released to Seller upon settlement for less than the
        funded amount or released to Buyer to pay any settlement or award exceeding the demand; and
    (ii) Continue to fund defense costs for such arbitration post-Closing up to a maximum of
         $75,000 per arbitration, after which Buyer shall control defense and settlement
         decisions at Buyer's cost (with indemnification rights against Litigation Escrow).
```

**Closing Condition (Article VI, Section 6.2(h): FINRA Arbitration Resolution):**
```
Seller shall have settled at least two of the three pending FINRA arbitrations prior to Closing,
with the aggregate settlement cost (including defense costs) for the settled arbitrations not
exceeding $800,000. If all three arbitrations remain pending at the Closing Date, Buyer may
(in its sole discretion):
    (i) Waive this condition and proceed to Closing, in which case Seller shall fund $1,500,000
        into the Litigation Escrow (in addition to the base $15,000,000) to cover the arbitrations
        plus a risk buffer; OR
    (ii) Terminate this Agreement and receive return of the Deposit plus reimbursement of
         out-of-pocket diligence costs up to $500,000.

The purpose of this condition is to prevent Thompson plaintiffs from obtaining FINRA arbitration
awards as evidence of unsuitable sales practices prior to Thompson mediation or trial, and to
eliminate the administrative burden on Buyer of managing three low-value arbitrations post-Closing.
```

#### E.3 Pre-Closing Conditions

| Condition | Trigger | Action Required | Responsible Party |
|-----------|---------|-----------------|-------------------|
| Chubb policy retroactive date verification | Within 15 days of purchase agreement execution | Produce declarations page and provide distribution of Thompson class members by policy issue date if retroactive date is post-2015 | Seller (document production) / Buyer (analysis) |
| Chubb consent to Thompson settlement structure | 60 days before anticipated settlement mediation | Engage Chubb coverage counsel, provide settlement term sheet to Chubb, obtain written confirmation that Chubb will pay $35M and not assert fraud or prior acts exclusion | Seller (with Buyer right to participate) |
| Tail coverage quote and purchase commitment | Within 30 days of purchase agreement execution | Obtain binding quote from Chubb for 3-year extended reporting period; Seller commits to purchase at Closing regardless of cost (up to $5M) | Seller / Insurance Broker |
| FINRA arbitration settlement progress | Monthly reporting; 2 of 3 settled before Closing | Mediate and settle FINRA arbitrations on economically reasonable terms; provide monthly status reports to Buyer | Seller (with Buyer consultation rights) |

#### E.4 Counter-Party Response Anticipation (TIER 3 ENHANCEMENT)

| Anticipated Seller Position | Likelihood | Buyer Response | Supporting Evidence |
|----------------------------|------------|----------------|---------------------|
| "Chubb tail coverage costs $4M; Buyer should split cost" | MEDIUM | Tail coverage is standard Seller closing deliverable in 75% of life insurance M&A deals; Buyer is paying purchase price that assumes no gap in E&O coverage | ABA M&A Committee Insurance Survey showing 72% of deals require Seller-funded tail; comparable deals (Pacific Life $4.5M tail, Jefferson National tail) |
| "Prior acts exclusion risk is speculative; no price adjustment warranted" | MEDIUM | Data room shows retroactive date is [DATE]; distribution of Thompson class shows [X]% of policies sold pre-retroactive date; Chubb may deny $[Y]M of coverage | Policy declarations page; class member distribution by issue date; insurance coverage opinion quantifying exposure |
| "Litigation escrow should be $8M (20% of $40M), not $15M" | HIGH | Base escrow calculation: $5M SIR + $2M opt-outs + $1.1M FINRA + $5M fraud exclusion buffer + $2M prior acts risk = $15.1M; market range 15-25% for E&O-covered litigation | Insurance industry benchmarks for litigation escrow sizing; precedent deals showing 20-30% escrows when coverage disputes possible |
| "FINRA arbitrations are immaterial ($1.1M); Seller will handle post-Closing" | MEDIUM | FINRA arbitrations create precedent risk for Thompson litigation; adverse awards usable as evidence of sales practice failures; settlements must occur before Thompson mediation | Thompson plaintiffs' ability to introduce FINRA awards as similar acts evidence under FRE 404(b); strategic imperative to eliminate evidence before mediation |

**Negotiation Strategy:**
1. **Opening Position**: Full tail coverage purchase by Seller ($3-4M), $15M litigation escrow with 36-month term, price adjustment for retroactive date if >25% of Thompson class excluded, FINRA arbitrations settled pre-Closing
2. **Target Position**: Tail coverage by Seller (non-negotiable), $12M litigation escrow with 30-month term, price adjustment for retroactive date if >40% excluded, 2 of 3 FINRA arbitrations settled pre-Closing
3. **Walk-Away**: No tail coverage + litigation escrow <$10M + no price adjustment for retroactive date excluding >50% of claims = deal breaks (acquirer inherits $20-40M uninsured exposure)
4. **Leverage Points**: (1) Thompson litigation is material deal risk; Seller has superior knowledge of coverage terms and can resolve uncertainties; (2) tail coverage market cost is $2.5-3.5M which is <1% of purchase price; (3) retroactive date verification is simple document production—refusal suggests adverse coverage position

**Response Playbook:**
- **If Seller argues tail coverage too expensive**: Counter with "obtain binding quote first, then discuss allocation; if cost exceeds $4M, parties split excess over $4M on 70/30 basis (Seller/Buyer)"
- **If Seller proposes lower litigation escrow**: Require Seller to obtain coverage counsel opinion confirming >90% probability Chubb pays $35M; if opinion not obtainable, escrow stays at $15M
- **If Seller refuses FINRA settlement pre-Closing**: Structure earnout tied to FINRA outcomes (if arbitrations cost <$800K, Seller receives $500K earnout; if >$1.2M, earnout forfeited); aligns incentives for efficient resolution
- **If Seller won't disclose retroactive date in diligence**: Walk away or require $15M price reduction (assumes worst-case 80% prior acts exclusion); information asymmetry favors Seller, so Buyer must price maximum risk

### ARTICLE VII — CLOSING CONDITIONS

#### Section 7.1  Vermont Captive Letter of Credit

The obligations of Buyer to consummate the Closing shall be subject to satisfaction or waiver of the following condition: Seller shall have caused Liberty Reinsurance VT LLC to obtain, and shall deliver to Buyer at Closing, an irrevocable, clean, unconditional letter of credit (the "**Vermont Captive LOC**") in the form attached as **Exhibit G**, satisfying the following requirements:

(a) **LOC Amount**: Four Hundred Million Dollars ($400,000,000);

(b) **LOC Issuer**: A U.S. banking institution rated AA- or better by Standard & Poor's Rating Services or Fitch Ratings, or Aa3 or better by Moody's Investors Service (acceptable issuers include JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A., Citibank, N.A., or Bank of America, N.A.);

(c) **Beneficiary**: Liberty Life Insurance Company (the "**Company**");

(d) **Term**: Five (5) years from the Closing Date, automatically renewable for successive one-year periods unless the issuing bank provides ninety (90) days' prior written notice of non-renewal to the Company and Buyer;

(e) **Draw Conditions**: Beneficiary may draw upon the Vermont Captive LOC upon presentation to the issuing bank of beneficiary's certificate stating that (i) the Nebraska Department of Insurance has issued a written notice to the Company disallowing all or any portion of the reserve credit relating to the reinsurance transactions between the Company and Liberty Reinsurance VT LLC, or (ii) the Nebraska Department of Insurance has commenced formal proceedings to disallow such reserve credit and the Company reasonably determines that such disallowance is probable;

(f) **Purpose**: The Vermont Captive LOC shall provide collateral support for the reserve credit taken by the Company for reinsurance ceded to Liberty Reinsurance VT LLC, in compliance with Nebraska insurance laws and regulations and Actuarial Guideline 48 as adopted by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners.

For the avoidance of doubt, Buyer's obligation to close is contingent upon delivery of the Vermont Captive LOC at Closing. Seller shall bear all costs and expenses associated with obtaining the Vermont Captive LOC, including arrangement fees, issuance fees, and annual renewal fees. Seller shall execute a letter of credit term sheet with an acceptable LOC Issuer within sixty (60) days after the execution of this Agreement, and shall provide Buyer with written status updates every ten (10) Business Days thereafter until the Vermont Captive LOC is delivered. If Seller fails to deliver the Vermont Captive LOC at Closing, Buyer may terminate this Agreement pursuant to Section 9.1(d) without liability.

---

#### Section 7.2  AFH Direct Capital Funding

The obligations of Buyer to consummate the Closing shall be subject to satisfaction or waiver of the following condition: Assured Financial Holdings, Inc. ("**AFH**") shall have committed to provide, and shall provide at Closing, the capital support described below:

(a) **Direct Capital Injection**: AFH shall wire transfer to the Company at Closing the amount of One Hundred Fifty Million Dollars ($150,000,000) in immediately available funds. Such funds shall be applied by the Company to the purchase of surplus notes issued by the Company to AFH (the "**AFH Surplus Notes**") in accordance with the Surplus Notes Purchase Agreement in the form attached as **Exhibit H**.

(b) **Surplus Notes Terms**: The AFH Surplus Notes shall have the following terms:
    (i) **Principal Amount**: $150,000,000;
    (ii) **Maturity Date**: Ten (10) years from the Closing Date;
    (iii) **Interest Rate**: 5.1% per annum, calculated on an after-tax basis;
    (iv) **Interest Payment**: Quarterly in arrears, subject to prior written approval of the Nebraska Department of Insurance in accordance with Neb. Rev. Stat. section 44-510.02;
    (v) **Prepayment**: Permitted with fifteen (15) days' prior written notice, subject to prior written approval of the Nebraska Department of Insurance;
    (vi) **Subordination**: Subordinated to all policyholder claims and all other obligations of the Company except obligations expressly subordinated to the AFH Surplus Notes.

(c) **Regulatory Pre-Approval**: Seller shall obtain written approval from the Nebraska Department of Insurance for the issuance of the AFH Surplus Notes and the terms thereof no later than sixty (60) days prior to the anticipated Closing Date. Seller shall file the application for such approval within thirty (30) days after the execution of this Agreement and shall cooperate with Buyer to respond promptly to any questions or requests for additional information from the Nebraska Department of Insurance.

(d) **Parental Guarantee Assumption**: Concurrently with the Closing, AFH shall execute and deliver to the Company a guarantee in the form attached as **Exhibit I** (the "**AFH Guarantee**") pursuant to which AFH guarantees all obligations of Liberty Reinsurance VT LLC to the Company under the Reinsurance Agreement dated June 15, 2023. Upon execution and delivery of the AFH Guarantee, Liberty Life Holdings, Inc. shall be released from all obligations under the Parental Guarantee dated June 15, 2023 in favor of the Company (the "**Existing Parental Guarantee**"), and the Existing Parental Guarantee shall terminate and be of no further force or effect. The aggregate liability of AFH under the AFH Guarantee shall not exceed Seven Hundred Thirty Million Dollars ($730,000,000).

(e) **Funding Mechanics**: The $150,000,000 wire transfer described in subsection (a) shall be made directly from AFH to the Company. Under no circumstances shall such funds be transferred to or through Liberty Life Holdings, Inc. or any other Affiliate of Seller (other than the Company).

If AFH fails or refuses to provide the Direct Capital Injection or execute the AFH Guarantee, Buyer may (i) terminate this Agreement pursuant to Section 9.1(d) without liability, or (ii) proceed to Closing with a Purchase Price reduction of One Hundred Fifty Million Dollars ($150,000,000).

---

#### Section 7.3  Agent and Producer Retention Program

The obligations of Buyer to consummate the Closing shall be subject to satisfaction or waiver of the following condition: Seller shall have established, funded, and implemented an agent and producer retention program (the "**Retention Program**") satisfying the following requirements:

(a) **Captive Agent Retention Component**:
    (i) **Aggregate Funding**: Twenty-Two Million Dollars ($22,000,000);
    (ii) **Eligible Participants**: All captive agents of the Company actively producing business as of the date of this Agreement (approximately 650 agents);
    (iii) **Payment Schedule**: Fifty percent (50%) of each eligible agent's retention payment shall be paid twelve (12) months after the Closing Date, and the remaining fifty percent (50%) shall be paid twenty-four (24) months after the Closing Date, in each case subject to the agent's continued active production of business for the Company;
    (iv) **Participation Threshold**: Retention agreements shall have been executed by agents representing at least ninety percent (90%) of the total number of eligible captive agents prior to Closing.

(b) **Independent Producer Retention Component**:
    (i) **Aggregate Funding**: Twenty-Four Million Dollars ($24,000,000);
    (ii) **Eligible Participants**: The top two hundred (200) independent insurance producers ranked by annual premium production volume for the Company during the twelve (12) months preceding the date of this Agreement;
    (iii) **Incentive Structure**: Production bonus equal to five percent (5%) of gross written premium produced by such independent producer during the first twelve (12) months following the Closing Date, payable quarterly in arrears;
    (iv) **Participation Threshold**: Production bonus agreements shall have been executed by independent producers representing at least eighty-five percent (85%) of the aggregate premium production volume of the top two hundred (200) independent producers during the twelve (12) months preceding the date of this Agreement.

(c) **Funding Mechanism**: At Closing, Seller shall deliver evidence reasonably satisfactory to Buyer that (i) the aggregate amount of Forty-Six Million Dollars ($46,000,000) has been deposited into an escrow account with an escrow agent mutually acceptable to Buyer and Seller pursuant to an escrow agreement in the form attached as **Exhibit J**, or (ii) such amount has been accrued as a liability on the balance sheet of the Company in accordance with GAAP and is reflected in the Closing Statement delivered pursuant to Section 2.5.

(d) **Program Documentation**: No later than thirty (30) days after the execution of this Agreement, Seller shall provide Buyer with the proposed terms and conditions of the Retention Program for Buyer's review and reasonable approval. Seller shall use commercially reasonable efforts to execute retention agreements with eligible participants within thirty (30) days after the Closing Date.

If the participation thresholds set forth in subsections (a)(iv) and (b)(iv) are not achieved prior to Closing, Buyer may (i) waive this condition and proceed to Closing, (ii) terminate this Agreement pursuant to Section 9.1(d) without liability, or (iii) proceed to Closing with a Purchase Price reduction of One Hundred Million Dollars ($100,000,000).

---

#### Section 7.4  IUL Class Action Settlement Approval

The obligations of Buyer to consummate the Closing shall be subject to satisfaction or waiver of the following condition: The class action litigation styled *Thompson v. Liberty Life Insurance Company*, Case No. CV-2023-1847, pending in the District Court of Douglas County, Nebraska (the "**IUL Class Action**"), shall have been settled and such settlement shall have received final judicial approval, subject to the following requirements:

(a) **Settlement Execution**: The Company shall have executed a definitive class action settlement agreement with counsel for the plaintiff class (the "**Settlement Agreement**") on or before March 31, 2025. The Settlement Agreement shall provide for the establishment of a settlement fund to compensate class members for claims relating to alleged misrepresentations regarding the performance of indexed universal life insurance policies issued by the Company.

(b) **Court Approval**: The District Court of Douglas County, Nebraska shall have entered an order granting final approval of the Settlement Agreement on or before June 30, 2025. Such final approval order shall not be subject to any appeal or motion for reconsideration, or the time for filing any such appeal or motion shall have expired without any such appeal or motion having been filed.

(c) **Settlement Amount**: The total settlement fund under the Settlement Agreement shall not exceed Forty Million Dollars ($40,000,000), inclusive of all class member payments, notice and administration costs, attorneys' fees and costs, and any incentive awards to class representatives.

(d) **E&O Insurance Confirmation**: The Company's errors and omissions insurance carrier, Federal Insurance Company (Chubb) (the "**E&O Insurer**"), shall have confirmed in writing that (i) the E&O Insurance Policy No. 8352-1947 provides coverage for the claims asserted in the IUL Class Action in an aggregate amount not less than Thirty-Five Million Dollars ($35,000,000), (ii) no fraud or intentional misconduct exclusion applies to bar or limit such coverage, and (iii) the E&O Insurer has no basis to rescind or deny coverage under the policy.

(e) **Pre-Closing Funding**: Seller shall fund the settlement amount (excluding any portion covered by the E&O Insurer) prior to the Closing Date. Evidence of such funding reasonably satisfactory to Buyer shall be delivered at Closing. Under no circumstances shall the Company be required to fund any portion of the settlement amount from the Company's assets or capital.

(f) **Mediation Process**: Seller shall participate in good faith in mediation of the IUL Class Action during the period from January 1, 2025 through March 31, 2025, and shall use commercially reasonable efforts to achieve a negotiated settlement within the parameters set forth in subsection (c).

If the Settlement Agreement is not executed by March 31, 2025, Buyer may (i) terminate this Agreement pursuant to Section 9.1(d) without liability, or (ii) elect to proceed to Closing subject to (A) an increase in the Tier 3 Escrow Amount (as defined in Section 2.4(c)) by Fifty Million Dollars ($50,000,000), and (B) a Purchase Price reduction of Twenty-Five Million Dollars ($25,000,000). If final court approval is not obtained by June 30, 2025, but a Settlement Agreement has been executed and preliminary approval has been granted, Buyer may elect to proceed to Closing subject to the escrow increase and price reduction described in the preceding sentence. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this Agreement, if the District Court schedules the IUL Class Action for trial on a date prior to the anticipated Closing Date, Buyer may terminate this Agreement pursuant to Section 9.1(d) without liability.

---

#### Section 7.5  Global Re Consent

The obligations of Buyer to consummate the Closing shall be subject to satisfaction or waiver of the following condition: Global Reinsurance Corporation ("**Global Re**") shall have consented to the assignment or change of control of the Reinsurance Agreement dated December 1, 2021 between the Company and Global Re (the "**Global Re Reinsurance Agreement**") in accordance with Section 12.8 thereof, subject to the following requirements:

(a) **Consent Request**: Within ten (10) Business Days after the execution of this Agreement, Seller shall submit to Global Re a written request for consent to the change of control of the Company resulting from the transactions contemplated by this Agreement (the "**Consent Request**"). The Consent Request shall be in the form attached as **Exhibit K** and shall include such information regarding Buyer and its financial condition as Global Re may reasonably require.

(b) **Consent Standard**: Global Re shall have delivered to Seller and Buyer a written consent to the change of control (the "**Global Re Consent**") that does not contain any modifications to the Global Re Reinsurance Agreement that are materially adverse to the Company or Buyer. For purposes of this Section 7.5, a modification shall be deemed "materially adverse" if it would reasonably be expected to result in a net present value impact to the Company or Buyer exceeding Fifty Million Dollars ($50,000,000), including but not limited to:
    (i) Any increase in ceding commission rates, recapture charges, or other fees payable by the Company to Global Re;
    (ii) Any reduction in reinsurance coverage limits or expansion of exclusions from coverage;
    (iii) Any acceleration of recapture rights or modification of recapture provisions that would permit Global Re to recapture reinsured policies prior to the recapture dates set forth in the Global Re Reinsurance Agreement as in effect on the date of this Agreement;
    (iv) Any increase in collateral or letter of credit requirements imposed on the Company.

(c) **Review Period**: Global Re shall have a period of ninety (90) days from the date of the Consent Request to review and respond to the Consent Request. Seller and Buyer shall cooperate to provide Global Re with any additional information reasonably requested by Global Re during such review period.

(d) **Anti-Recapture Negotiation**: If Global Re conditions its consent upon modifications to the Global Re Reinsurance Agreement relating to recapture provisions, Seller shall negotiate with Global Re in good faith to minimize the economic impact of such modifications. Seller's authority to agree to economic concessions in connection with such negotiations shall not exceed Forty Million Dollars ($40,000,000) in net present value without Buyer's prior written consent.

(e) **Alternative Closing Conditions**: If Global Re has not delivered the Global Re Consent as of the Closing Date, but has not denied or conditioned its consent in a manner that would violate subsection (b), Buyer may elect to proceed to Closing subject to an increase in the Tier 2 Escrow Amount (as defined in Section 2.4(b)) by Fifty Million Dollars ($50,000,000), which additional escrow amount shall be released in accordance with Section 2.4(b) upon receipt of the Global Re Consent in accordance with this Section 7.5.

If Global Re denies the Consent Request or conditions its consent upon modifications that are materially adverse to the Company or Buyer (as determined under subsection (b)), Buyer may (i) terminate this Agreement pursuant to Section 9.1(d) without liability, or (ii) elect to proceed to Closing with such modifications if Buyer determines in its sole discretion that the modifications are acceptable notwithstanding their material adverse nature.

(b) **Escrow Deposits**. At the Closing, Buyer shall deposit with the Escrow Agent, by wire transfer of immediately available funds, an aggregate amount equal to One Hundred Eighty-Five Million Dollars ($185,000,000) (the "**Total Escrow Amount**"), to be allocated among three separate escrow accounts as follows:

    (i) One Hundred Million Dollars ($100,000,000) into the Tier 1 Escrow Account (as defined in Section 9.2);

    (ii) Fifty Million Dollars ($50,000,000) into the Tier 2 Escrow Account (as defined in Section 9.3); and

    (iii) Thirty-Five Million Dollars ($35,000,000) into the Tier 3 Escrow Account (as defined in Section 9.4).

(c) **Investment of Escrow Funds**. The Escrow Agent shall invest the amounts held in the escrow accounts in (i) direct obligations of the United States of America, (ii) obligations fully guaranteed by the United States of America, (iii) certificates of deposit or time deposits of any commercial bank having capital and surplus in excess of $500,000,000, (iv) commercial paper rated at least A-1 by Standard & Poor's Corporation or P-1 by Moody's Investors Service, Inc., or (v) money market funds investing solely in securities of the type described in clauses (i) through (iv). All investment earnings shall be allocated to the respective escrow accounts and shall be released together with the principal amount of such escrow account in accordance with this Article IX.

(d) **Tax Allocation**. For U.S. federal and applicable state and local income tax purposes, Seller shall be treated as the owner of the escrow accounts, and Seller shall report and pay all taxes on any income earned on the funds deposited in such accounts. The Escrow Agent shall file all tax information returns required by Law, including IRS Form 1099, with respect to the escrow accounts, and Seller shall provide the Escrow Agent with a properly completed IRS Form W-9 and any other reasonably requested tax documentation.

(e) **Escrow Agent Fees**. All fees and expenses of the Escrow Agent shall be borne equally by Buyer and Seller. The Parties shall pay such fees and expenses directly to the Escrow Agent within ten (10) Business Days after receipt of an invoice therefor, and in no event shall such fees and expenses be paid from the escrow accounts.

#### Section 9.2  Tier 1 Escrow (Captive Recapture Risk)

(a) **Amount and Term**. At the Closing, Buyer shall deposit with the Escrow Agent One Hundred Million Dollars ($100,000,000) (the "**Tier 1 Escrow Amount**") to be held in a segregated escrow account (the "**Tier 1 Escrow Account**") for a period of thirty-six (36) months following the Closing Date (the "**Tier 1 Escrow Period**").

(b) **Release Conditions**. The Escrow Agent shall release the Tier 1 Escrow Amount (plus any accrued interest) to Seller upon the earliest to occur of:

    (i) Buyer's delivery to the Escrow Agent of written confirmation from the Nebraska Department of Insurance stating that the $850,000,000 reserve credit relating to the reinsurance transactions between the Company and Liberty Reinsurance VT LLC remains valid, complies with applicable regulatory requirements including Actuarial Guideline 48, and will not be subject to disallowance or adjustment; or

    (ii) Buyer's delivery to the Escrow Agent of (A) evidence satisfactory to the Escrow Agent that the Company and Liberty Reinsurance VT LLC have executed and delivered the Vermont Captive LOC satisfying the requirements of Section 7.1, and (B) written acknowledgment from the Nebraska Department of Insurance that such LOC has been filed with and is acceptable to the Nebraska Department of Insurance; or

    (iii) Expiration of the Tier 1 Escrow Period without Buyer having delivered a Notice of Claim (as defined in Section 9.6) with respect to a Captive Recapture Event.

(c) **Captive Recapture Event**. For purposes of this Agreement, "**Captive Recapture Event**" means the Nebraska Department of Insurance has (i) issued a written notice to the Company disallowing all or any portion of the reserve credit relating to the reinsurance transactions between the Company and Liberty Reinsurance VT LLC, or (ii) formally commenced proceedings to disallow such reserve credit, or (iii) issued any formal guidance, bulletin, or order indicating that such reserve credit does not comply with Actuarial Guideline 48 or other applicable regulatory requirements and must be remediated, replaced, or otherwise adjusted.

(d) **Tier 1 Claims**. If a Captive Recapture Event occurs during the Tier 1 Escrow Period, Buyer may deliver a Notice of Claim to Seller and the Escrow Agent in accordance with Section 9.6. The amount of any Tier 1 Claim shall equal the actual economic loss suffered by the Company as a result of the Captive Recapture Event, including (i) the cost of obtaining replacement reserve credit (including any LOC fees, collateral posting costs, or increased reinsurance premiums), (ii) any regulatory penalties or fines imposed by the Nebraska Department of Insurance, (iii) any required capital injections to maintain the Company's Risk-Based Capital ratio at or above the Action Level as a result of the reserve credit disallowance, and (iv) reasonable attorneys' fees and consulting fees incurred in responding to the Captive Recapture Event, up to a maximum aggregate amount equal to the Tier 1 Escrow Amount.

#### Section 9.3  Tier 2 Escrow (Global Re Consent Risk)

(a) **Amount and Term**. At the Closing, Buyer shall deposit with the Escrow Agent Fifty Million Dollars ($50,000,000) (the "**Tier 2 Escrow Amount**") to be held in a segregated escrow account (the "**Tier 2 Escrow Account**") for a period of twenty-four (24) months following the Closing Date (the "**Tier 2 Escrow Period**").

(b) **Release Conditions**. The Escrow Agent shall release the Tier 2 Escrow Amount (plus any accrued interest) to Seller upon the earliest to occur of:

    (i) Buyer's delivery to the Escrow Agent of a copy of the written consent from Global Reinsurance Corporation of America ("**Global Re**") to the assignment and novation of the Quota Share Reinsurance Agreement dated June 15, 2022 (the "**Global Re Consent**"), in form and substance reasonably satisfactory to Buyer and without any material modifications to the terms and conditions of such Quota Share Reinsurance Agreement that would (A) increase the Company's obligations or liabilities thereunder by more than $5,000,000 in the aggregate, (B) reduce the reinsurance coverage provided to the Company by more than 5% on a net present value basis, or (C) grant Global Re any termination right not contained in the original Quota Share Reinsurance Agreement (collectively, "**Materially Adverse Modifications**"); or

    (ii) Expiration of the Tier 2 Escrow Period without Buyer having delivered a Notice of Claim with respect to a Global Re Consent Failure.

(c) **Global Re Consent Failure**. For purposes of this Agreement, "**Global Re Consent Failure**" means either (i) Global Re has delivered written notice to the Company or Buyer refusing to provide the Global Re Consent, or (ii) Global Re has not delivered the Global Re Consent within twelve (12) months after the Closing Date (the "**Consent Deadline**").

(d) **Tier 2 Claims**. If a Global Re Consent Failure occurs during the Tier 2 Escrow Period, Buyer may deliver a Notice of Claim to Seller and the Escrow Agent in accordance with Section 9.6. The amount of any Tier 2 Claim shall equal the actual economic loss suffered by the Company as a result of the Global Re Consent Failure, including (i) the cost of obtaining replacement reinsurance coverage on substantially equivalent terms, (ii) any unrecovered loss exposures resulting from the loss of Global Re coverage, (iii) any lost profit-sharing or experience account credits under the original Quota Share Reinsurance Agreement, and (iv) reasonable attorneys' fees and consulting fees incurred in addressing the Global Re Consent Failure, up to a maximum aggregate amount equal to the Tier 2 Escrow Amount.

(e) **Seller Cooperation**. Following the Closing, Seller shall use commercially reasonable efforts to cooperate with Buyer in obtaining the Global Re Consent, including (i) providing Global Re with any financial or operational information reasonably requested, (ii) participating in meetings or conference calls with Global Re as reasonably requested by Buyer, and (iii) negotiating in good faith any reasonable modifications to the Quota Share Reinsurance Agreement proposed by Global Re that would not constitute Materially Adverse Modifications. Notwithstanding the foregoing, Seller shall have no obligation to incur any out-of-pocket expense or grant any material accommodation or concession to Global Re in connection with obtaining the Global Re Consent.

#### Section 9.4  Tier 3 Escrow (Thompson Litigation Risk)

(a) **Amount and Term**. At the Closing, Buyer shall deposit with the Escrow Agent Thirty-Five Million Dollars ($35,000,000) (the "**Tier 3 Escrow Amount**") to be held in a segregated escrow account (the "**Tier 3 Escrow Account**") for a period of eighteen (18) months following the Closing Date or, if later, until the date that is sixty (60) days after the date on which the Thompson Settlement Approval becomes final and non-appealable (the "**Tier 3 Escrow Period**").

(b) **Release Conditions**. The Escrow Agent shall release the Tier 3 Escrow Amount (plus any accrued interest) to Seller upon satisfaction of all of the following conditions (the "**Thompson Settlement Conditions**"):

    (i) The United States District Court for the District of Nebraska has entered a final order approving the settlement of the putative class action captioned *Thompson v. Midwest Family Life Insurance Company*, Case No. 4:23-cv-03089 (D. Neb.) (the "**Thompson Litigation**") on the terms set forth in the Settlement Agreement filed with the Court on September 12, 2025 (the "**Thompson Settlement Agreement**"), and such order has become final and non-appealable (the "**Thompson Settlement Approval**");

    (ii) The opt-out rate for the Thompson Litigation settlement class does not exceed two percent (2.0%) of the total number of class members;

    (iii) Chubb Insurance Company of New Jersey, the issuer of the Company's directors and officers liability insurance policy No. D&O-8847392 (the "**Chubb E&O Policy**"), has delivered written confirmation to the Company or Buyer that (A) the Thompson Litigation settlement is covered under the Chubb E&O Policy, (B) Chubb will pay the full $35,000,000 settlement amount on behalf of the Company, and (C) Chubb has not invoked and will not invoke any fraud or intentional misconduct exclusion with respect to such payment (the "**Chubb Coverage Confirmation**"); and

    (iv) Buyer has delivered to the Escrow Agent evidence satisfactory to the Escrow Agent that all of the foregoing conditions have been satisfied.

(c) **Thompson Litigation Adverse Event**. For purposes of this Agreement, "**Thompson Litigation Adverse Event**" means any of the following:

    (i) The Court denies approval of the Thompson Settlement Agreement;

    (ii) The Thompson Settlement Approval is reversed, vacated, or materially modified on appeal;

    (iii) The opt-out rate for the settlement class exceeds two percent (2.0%);

    (iv) Chubb refuses to provide the Chubb Coverage Confirmation or invokes any fraud or intentional misconduct exclusion to deny or reduce coverage for the Thompson Litigation settlement; or

    (v) The Thompson Settlement Agreement is terminated in accordance with its terms prior to receiving final court approval.

(d) **Tier 3 Claims**. If a Thompson Litigation Adverse Event occurs during the Tier 3 Escrow Period, Buyer may deliver a Notice of Claim to Seller and the Escrow Agent in accordance with Section 9.6. The amount of any Tier 3 Claim shall equal the actual economic loss suffered by the Company as a result of the Thompson Litigation Adverse Event, including (i) any judgment, settlement amount, or other liability incurred by the Company in the Thompson Litigation (or in any related litigation brought by opt-out class members) that is not covered by the Chubb E&O Policy or other insurance, (ii) any deductible, self-insured retention, or coinsurance amount borne by the Company under the Chubb E&O Policy, (iii) any defense costs and attorneys' fees incurred by the Company that are not reimbursed by insurance, and (iv) any civil penalties or regulatory fines imposed on the Company arising out of the facts and circumstances underlying the Thompson Litigation, up to a maximum aggregate amount equal to the Tier 3 Escrow Amount.

(e) **Automatic Extension**. If the Thompson Settlement Approval has not become final and non-appealable within eighteen (18) months after the Closing Date, the Tier 3 Escrow Period shall automatically extend for successive ninety (90) day periods until the earlier of (i) satisfaction of all Thompson Settlement Conditions, or (ii) occurrence of a Thompson Litigation Adverse Event, or (iii) the date that is forty-eight (48) months after the Closing Date. Seller or Buyer may deliver written notice to the other Party and the Escrow Agent confirming such automatic extension.

#### Section 9.5  Release Procedures

(a) **Release Notice**. Upon satisfaction of the release conditions for any escrow account under Sections 9.2(b), 9.3(b), or 9.4(b), the Party entitled to the release (or either Party, if the release is due to expiration of the escrow period without claims) shall deliver to the Escrow Agent and the other Party a written notice (a "**Release Notice**") stating that the applicable release conditions have been satisfied and instructing the Escrow Agent to release the applicable escrow amount to Seller. The Release Notice shall include reasonable supporting documentation evidencing satisfaction of the release conditions.

(b) **Objection Right**. The Party receiving a Release Notice (the "**Non-Requesting Party**") shall have ten (10) Business Days after receipt of the Release Notice to deliver a written objection to the Escrow Agent and the requesting Party (an "**Objection Notice**"). The Objection Notice must specify with reasonable particularity the basis for the objection and the reasons why the Non-Requesting Party believes the release conditions have not been satisfied.

(c) **Release Without Objection**. If the Escrow Agent does not receive an Objection Notice within the ten (10) Business Day period described in Section 9.5(b), the Escrow Agent shall release the applicable escrow amount (plus accrued interest) to Seller within three (3) Business Days thereafter by wire transfer of immediately available funds to the account designated by Seller.

(d) **Resolution of Objections**. If the Escrow Agent receives a timely Objection Notice, the Parties shall negotiate in good faith for a period of thirty (30) days to resolve the dispute. If the Parties resolve the dispute within such thirty (30) day period, they shall deliver joint written instructions to the Escrow Agent directing the disposition of the disputed escrow amount. If the Parties are unable to resolve the dispute within such thirty (30) day period, either Party may submit the dispute for resolution in accordance with Section 9.7.

#### Section 9.6  Claims Against Escrow

(a) **Notice of Claim**. If Buyer becomes aware of a matter that Buyer believes constitutes a Captive Recapture Event, Global Re Consent Failure, or Thompson Litigation Adverse Event (each, a "**Claim Event**"), Buyer may deliver a written notice to Seller and the Escrow Agent (a "**Notice of Claim**") at any time during the applicable escrow period. The Notice of Claim must contain:

    (i) A description of the Claim Event in reasonable detail, including the date on which the Claim Event occurred or was discovered;

    (ii) The specific escrow tier(s) against which the claim is being asserted;

    (iii) The amount of Losses claimed (the "**Claimed Amount**"), including a reasonably detailed calculation of such amount and the factual basis for such calculation;

    (iv) Copies of any material documentation supporting the existence of the Claim Event and the calculation of Losses; and

    (v) A statement that Buyer has made such investigation of the Claim Event as is reasonable under the circumstances.

(b) **Claim Amount Cap**. The Claimed Amount in any Notice of Claim shall not exceed the then-remaining balance of the applicable escrow tier(s). If a Claim Event could reasonably be expected to result in Losses exceeding the balance of a single escrow tier, Buyer may assert claims against multiple escrow tiers, provided that Buyer specifies the allocation of the Claimed Amount among such tiers.

(c) **Seller's Response**. Within thirty (30) days after receipt of a Notice of Claim, Seller may deliver a written response to Buyer and the Escrow Agent (a "**Claim Response**") either (i) agreeing to the claim and instructing the Escrow Agent to pay the Claimed Amount to Buyer, or (ii) disputing all or any portion of the claim and setting forth in reasonable detail the basis for such dispute. If Seller delivers a Claim Response agreeing to the claim, the Escrow Agent shall pay the Claimed Amount to Buyer within five (5) Business Days by wire transfer of immediately available funds to the account designated by Buyer.

(d) **Disputed Claims**. If Seller delivers a Claim Response disputing all or any portion of a claim, or if Seller fails to deliver any Claim Response within the thirty (30) day period (in which case Seller shall be deemed to have disputed the entire claim), the Parties shall negotiate in good faith for a period of thirty (30) days to resolve the dispute. If the Parties resolve the dispute within such period, they shall deliver joint written instructions to the Escrow Agent directing the disposition of the disputed amount. If the Parties are unable to resolve the dispute within such period, either Party may submit the dispute for resolution in accordance with Section 9.7.

(e) **Segregation of Disputed Amounts**. Upon receipt of a Notice of Claim that is disputed by Seller, the Escrow Agent shall segregate and continue to hold the Claimed Amount (up to the available balance of the applicable escrow tier) pending resolution of the dispute. The Escrow Agent shall release any remaining undisputed portion of the escrow account in accordance with the applicable release conditions under this Article IX.

(f) **Survival of Claims**. A Notice of Claim delivered to the Escrow Agent prior to expiration of the applicable escrow period shall survive such expiration, and the Escrow Agent shall continue to hold the Claimed Amount until the dispute is resolved in accordance with this Article IX. The applicable escrow period shall be extended solely with respect to the Claimed Amount until final resolution of the claim.

#### Section 9.7  Dispute Resolution

(a) **Arbitration**. Any dispute arising under this Article IX that the Parties are unable to resolve through good faith negotiation shall be resolved by binding arbitration in accordance with this Section 9.7. Either Party may initiate arbitration by delivering written notice to the other Party and the Escrow Agent specifying the nature of the dispute and the relief sought.

(b) **Arbitration Procedures**. The arbitration shall be conducted in Omaha, Nebraska, in accordance with the Commercial Arbitration Rules of the American Arbitration Association (the "**AAA**"), as modified by this Section 9.7. The arbitration shall be conducted by a single arbitrator mutually acceptable to both Parties. If the Parties cannot agree on an arbitrator within fifteen (15) days after initiation of the arbitration, the AAA shall appoint an arbitrator who (i) is a retired federal or state judge or an attorney with at least twenty (20) years of experience in complex commercial disputes, and (ii) has no current or prior professional or personal relationship with either Party or their respective Affiliates.

(c) **Expedited Schedule**. The arbitrator shall conduct the arbitration on an expedited basis and shall issue a final written decision within sixty (60) days after appointment. The arbitrator may permit limited discovery, including document production and depositions, as the arbitrator deems necessary to resolve the dispute fairly and efficiently. The arbitrator shall apply the substantive law of Delaware and may award any relief that would be available in a court of law or equity, including payment from the escrow account, specific performance, or declaratory relief.

(d) **Final and Binding**. The arbitrator's decision shall be final, binding, and non-appealable, and judgment upon the award rendered by the arbitrator may be entered in any court having jurisdiction. The Parties irrevocably waive any right to appeal the arbitrator's decision, except on the grounds specified in the Federal Arbitration Act.

(e) **Costs**. Each Party shall bear its own attorneys' fees and costs in connection with any arbitration, except that the arbitrator may award attorneys' fees and costs to the prevailing Party if the arbitrator determines that the non-prevailing Party's position was frivolous or brought in bad faith. The Parties shall share equally the fees and expenses of the arbitrator and the AAA.

(f) **Instructions to Escrow Agent**. Upon resolution of any dispute through arbitration, the Parties shall promptly deliver joint written instructions to the Escrow Agent directing the disposition of any disputed escrow amounts in accordance with the arbitrator's decision. If either Party fails to execute such joint instructions within five (5) Business Days after the arbitrator's decision, the other Party may deliver a copy of the arbitrator's decision to the Escrow Agent, and the Escrow Agent shall comply with such decision.

#### Section 9.8  General Escrow Provisions

(a) **Escrow Agent as Stakeholder**. The Escrow Agent shall act solely as a stakeholder and shall have no duties or obligations other than those expressly set forth in this Agreement and the Escrow Agreement. The Escrow Agent shall have no implied duties or fiduciary obligations to either Party and shall not be required to make any independent investigation or determination regarding the matters set forth in this Article IX.

(b) **Reliance on Instructions**. The Escrow Agent shall be entitled to rely conclusively on any written instruction or notice delivered by either Party pursuant to this Article IX, and shall have no duty to inquire into or investigate the truth, accuracy, or validity of any such instruction or notice. The Escrow Agent may request from the Parties any additional documentation or evidence it reasonably deems necessary to confirm its obligations hereunder.

(c) **Indemnification of Escrow Agent**. Each Party shall indemnify and hold harmless the Escrow Agent from and against any and all losses, liabilities, damages, costs, and expenses (including reasonable attorneys' fees) arising out of or in connection with the Escrow Agent's performance of its duties under this Agreement and the Escrow Agreement, except to the extent resulting from the Escrow Agent's gross negligence or willful misconduct. The indemnification obligations under this Section 9.8(c) shall be borne equally by Buyer and Seller.

(d) **Resignation of Escrow Agent**. The Escrow Agent may resign at any time upon thirty (30) days' prior written notice to the Parties. In the event of such resignation, the Parties shall jointly appoint a successor escrow agent reasonably acceptable to both Parties. If the Parties are unable to agree on a successor escrow agent within thirty (30) days after receipt of the resignation notice, either Party may petition a court of competent jurisdiction to appoint a successor escrow agent. The resigning Escrow Agent shall deliver the escrow funds to the successor escrow agent upon receipt of written acceptance of appointment from the successor.

(e) **Interpleader**. If the Escrow Agent becomes subject to conflicting claims or demands regarding any escrow funds, or if the Escrow Agent is uncertain as to its obligations hereunder, the Escrow Agent may (i) decline to take any action until it receives joint written instructions from the Parties, or (ii) deposit the escrow funds with a court of competent jurisdiction and interplead the Parties, in which case the Escrow Agent shall be relieved of all further obligations hereunder with respect to such escrow funds. The Parties shall reimburse the Escrow Agent for all costs and expenses (including reasonable attorneys' fees) incurred in connection with any interpleader action, such reimbursement to be borne equally by the Parties unless a court orders otherwise.

(f) **Source of Payments**. All payments to be made by Buyer pursuant to this Article IX shall be made from Buyer's own funds and not from any funds or assets of the Company or its Subsidiaries. For the avoidance of doubt, the escrow deposits required under Section 9.1(b) constitute a portion of the Purchase Price and shall be funded by Buyer at Closing in addition to the cash payment to be made to Seller under Section 3.2.

(g) **No Offset**. Seller's right to receive payment from the escrow accounts in accordance with this Article IX shall not be subject to any offset, counterclaim, or other defense by Buyer, except for claims properly asserted against the escrow accounts in accordance with Section 9.6. Buyer shall not have any right to offset any amounts due to Seller from the escrow accounts against any other amounts that may be owed by Seller to Buyer under this Agreement or otherwise.

(h) **Relationship to Indemnification**. The escrow accounts established pursuant to this Article IX are separate and independent from the indemnification provisions set forth in Article X. Buyer's right to recover Losses from the escrow accounts with respect to the specific Claim Events defined in this Article IX shall not limit or impair Buyer's indemnification rights under Article X with respect to breaches of representations, warranties, or covenants. However, Buyer shall not be entitled to recover duplicate or overlapping Losses with respect to the same matter under both this Article IX and Article X.

# ARTICLE X
# INDEMNIFICATION

## Section 10.1  Indemnification by Seller

Subject to the limitations set forth in this Article X, from and after the Closing, Seller shall indemnify, defend, and hold harmless Buyer, the Company, and their respective Affiliates, officers, directors, employees, agents, successors, and assigns (collectively, the "**Buyer Indemnified Parties**") from and against any and all Losses arising out of or resulting from:

(a) **Breach of Representations and Warranties**. Any breach of any representation or warranty made by Seller in this Agreement or in any certificate delivered by Seller pursuant to this Agreement;

(b) **Breach of Covenants**. Any breach of any covenant or agreement of Seller contained in this Agreement;

(c) **Captive Recapture Event**. Any Captive Recapture Event (as defined in Section 9.2(c)) occurring prior to the expiration of the Tier 1 Escrow Period, including without limitation:

> (i) any capital contribution required to restore the Company's Risk-Based Capital ratio to at least 200% of Company Action Level following disallowance of reserve credit by the Nebraska Department of Insurance with respect to the Vermont Captive Reinsurance Agreement;
>
> (ii) any Losses resulting from the Company's inability to obtain a qualifying letter of credit to replace reserve credit under 11 Neb. Admin. Code § 80-004;
>
> (iii) any regulatory sanctions, fines, or penalties imposed by the Nebraska Department of Insurance related to non-compliance with captive reinsurance requirements; and
>
> (iv) any costs incurred to unwind, novate, or restructure the Vermont Captive Reinsurance Agreement;

(d) **Thompson Litigation Excess**. Any Losses incurred by the Company in connection with the *Thompson v. Liberty Life Insurance Company* class action litigation (Case No. CI-23-5418, Nebraska District Court) to the extent such Losses exceed Forty Million Dollars ($40,000,000) net of insurance recoveries under the Company's errors and omissions liability policy, including without limitation:

> (i) settlement payments or judgments exceeding such threshold;
>
> (ii) defense costs to the extent not covered by insurance;
>
> (iii) claims administration costs; and
>
> (iv) any denial, rescission, or reduction of coverage under the errors and omissions policy;

(e) **Market Conduct Examination Excess**. Any fines, penalties, corrective action costs, premium refunds, policyholder restitution, or other monetary sanctions imposed by the Nebraska Department of Insurance in connection with the market conduct examination conducted in 2024 (Examination No. MC-2024-037) to the extent such amounts exceed One Million One Hundred Thousand Dollars ($1,100,000) in the aggregate;

(f) **FINRA Conditional Approval Costs**. Any material operational restrictions, activity limitations, enhanced supervision requirements, or compliance costs imposed by the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA) in connection with approval of the Form CMA application relating to the change of control of Liberty Life Securities LLC, to the extent such restrictions result in quantifiable revenue reduction or incremental compliance costs exceeding Five Hundred Thousand Dollars ($500,000) in the aggregate over any twelve-month period following Closing; and

(g) **Pre-Closing Taxes**. Any Taxes of the Company for any Pre-Closing Tax Period (as defined in Section 8.4), except to the extent reflected in the calculation of Closing Net Working Capital or otherwise taken into account in determining the Final Purchase Price.

## Section 10.2  Indemnification by Buyer

Subject to the limitations set forth in this Article X, from and after the Closing, Buyer shall indemnify, defend, and hold harmless Seller and its Affiliates, officers, directors, employees, agents, successors, and assigns (collectively, the "**Seller Indemnified Parties**") from and against any and all Losses arising out of or resulting from:

(a) **Breach of Representations and Warranties**. Any breach of any representation or warranty made by Buyer in this Agreement or in any certificate delivered by Buyer pursuant to this Agreement;

(b) **Breach of Covenants**. Any breach of any covenant or agreement of Buyer contained in this Agreement;

(c) **Post-Closing Operations**. Any Losses arising out of the operation of the Company's business following the Closing, except to the extent such Losses arise from or relate to matters for which Seller has an indemnification obligation under Section 10.1; and

(d) **Post-Closing Taxes**. Any Taxes of the Company for any Post-Closing Tax Period (as defined in Section 8.4), except to the extent Seller has an indemnification obligation under Section 10.1(g).

## Section 10.3  Limitations on Indemnification

(a) **Basket**. Seller shall not have any liability under Section 10.1(a) (indemnification for breach of representations and warranties) until the aggregate amount of Losses with respect to such matters exceeds Five Million Dollars ($5,000,000) (the "**Basket**"), and then only for the amount by which such Losses exceed the Basket; *provided, however*, that the Basket shall not apply to:

> (i) Losses arising out of or resulting from breaches of the Fundamental Representations (as defined in Section 10.4(b));
>
> (ii) the Specific Indemnities set forth in Section 10.1(c) through (g);
>
> (iii) Losses arising from fraud or willful misconduct; or
>
> (iv) Losses arising from breaches of covenants under Section 10.1(b).

(b) **Cap**. The aggregate liability of Seller under Section 10.1(a) (indemnification for breach of representations and warranties) shall not exceed Five Hundred Fifty-Two Million Dollars ($552,000,000) (the "**Cap**"), which amount represents twenty percent (20%) of the Adjusted Purchase Price as finally determined pursuant to Section 2.3; *provided, however*, that the Cap shall not apply to:

> (i) Losses arising out of or resulting from breaches of the Fundamental Representations;
>
> (ii) the Specific Indemnities set forth in Section 10.1(c) through (g), each of which shall be subject to its own stated limit or threshold;
>
> (iii) Losses arising from fraud or willful misconduct; or
>
> (iv) Losses arising from breaches of covenants under Section 10.1(b).

(c) **Buyer Indemnity Limitations**. The aggregate liability of Buyer under Section 10.2(a) (indemnification for breach of representations and warranties) shall be subject to a basket of Five Million Dollars ($5,000,000) and a cap of One Hundred Million Dollars ($100,000,000), except in the case of fraud or willful misconduct.

(d) **Mitigation**. Each Indemnified Party shall use commercially reasonable efforts to mitigate any Losses for which it seeks indemnification under this Article X, including by pursuing recovery under applicable insurance policies and from third parties. The amount of any Losses for which indemnification is available under this Article X shall be reduced by:

> (i) any insurance proceeds or other third-party recoveries actually received by the Indemnified Party with respect to such Losses (net of any costs of collection and any increase in insurance premiums attributable to such claim); and
>
> (ii) any net Tax benefit actually realized by the Indemnified Party as a result of such Losses in the taxable year in which the Loss is incurred or the immediately succeeding taxable year.

(e) **No Double Recovery**. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this Agreement, no Indemnified Party shall be entitled to recover more than once for the same Loss, whether through adjustment to the Purchase Price, indemnification under this Article X, recovery from the Escrow Amount, or otherwise.

(f) **No Consequential Damages**. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this Agreement, no party shall be liable to any other party for any punitive, exemplary, special, incidental, indirect, or consequential damages (including lost profits or diminution in value) in connection with this Agreement or the transactions contemplated hereby, except to the extent:

> (i) such damages are reasonably foreseeable and directly caused by fraud or willful misconduct; or
>
> (ii) such damages are awarded to a third party in a Third-Party Claim (as defined in Section 10.6) for which indemnification is required under this Article X.

## Section 10.4  Survival Periods

(a) **General Survival**. Subject to Section 10.4(b), (c), and (d), the representations and warranties of the parties contained in this Agreement or in any certificate delivered pursuant to this Agreement shall survive the Closing for a period of twenty-four (24) months following the Closing Date (the "**General Survival Period**"). No claim for indemnification under Section 10.1(a) or Section 10.2(a) may be made after the expiration of the applicable survival period, except for claims asserted in writing prior to such expiration and pending on such date.

(b) **Fundamental Representations**. Notwithstanding Section 10.4(a), the following representations and warranties (the "**Fundamental Representations**") shall survive until sixty (60) days following the expiration of the applicable statute of limitations:

> (i) Section 3.1 (Organization and Qualification);
>
> (ii) Section 3.2 (Authority; Enforceability);
>
> (iii) Section 3.3 (Capitalization) with respect to Seller's ownership of the Company Shares;
>
> (iv) Section 3.4 (No Conflicts);
>
> (v) Section 3.5 (Brokers' Fees) with respect to Seller's brokers; and
>
> (vi) Section 4.3 (Capitalization) with respect to the outstanding equity of the Company.

(c) **Special Survival Periods**. Notwithstanding Section 10.4(a), the following representations, warranties, covenants, and indemnity obligations shall survive for the periods specified below:

> (i) **Tax Matters**: Representations and warranties in Section 4.10 (Tax Matters) and indemnity obligations under Section 10.1(g) shall survive until sixty (60) days following the expiration of the applicable statute of limitations (including any extensions or waivers thereof);
